page.title: 19Stowmarket Early C20
page.content: Mr Lance Mayhew remembers Stowmarket as it was before the First World War. The market was larger then, spreading from the Market Place into Crowe Street,and including small livestock- chickens, rabbits- which are no longer seen today. Beneath the Market Place were the vaults used by a firm of wine merchants, no longer in the town, and the Corn Exchange was visible instead of being merged into various buildings as it is now. There were two windmills along Bury St, as well as some pig-sties. Goods were distributed mostly by horse and cart, but there were a few steam lorries and the machinery at Clover's Mill was steam-powered. Great excitement was caused when Lord Kitchener visited Stowmarket to inspect troops.
